si9.svg svg 6135 ALTIMG JECHEM 4810 S2095-4956(25)00510-8 10.1016/j.jechem.2025.06.036 Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Fig. 1 (a) Schematic illustration of PEO-LCy electrolyte with inner interaction situation. (b) Impedance spectra of SS|PEO-1%LCy|SS cell at different temperatures. (c) Arrhenius plots for PEO-LCy electrolytes with various contents of LCy filler. (d) LSV curves for PEO-1%LCy and pure PEO electrolytes. (e) SEM image and corresponding EDS mapping of PEO-LCy electrolyte. (f) Photographs of PEO-LCy electrolytes with different shapes showing super flexibility. Fig. 2 (a) Raman spectra of PEO-LCy electrolyte with different LCy contents in the ranges of 200–1600 and 728–755 cm−1. (b) Dissociation degree values of LiTFSI in PEO-LCy electrolyte with different contents of LCy. (c) Binding energies of Li+-TFSI−, PEO-Li+, LCy-TFSI− and PEO-TFSI− pairs. (d) Direct current polarization profile of Li‖Li symmetric cell with PEO-LCy. Inset: corresponding impedance spectra before and after polarization. (e) Electrostatic potential distribution images of PEO, LiTFSI, LCy and PEO-LCy. Migration energy barrier profiles of Li+ in (f) PEO and (g) PEO-LCy. Fig. 3 Snapshots of molecular dynamics (MD) simulation box of (a) PEO-LiTFSI and (b) PEO-LCy at 60 °C. (c) Solvation structures and interaction situations in PEO-LiTFSI and PEO-LCy. Calculated radial distribution functions and coordination numbers of (d) Li–O (from TFSI) and (e) Li–O (from PEO) for PEO-LiTFSI and PEO-LCy electrolytes. (f) Multiple interactions and Li+ transport mechanism in PEO-LCy electrolyte. Fig. 4 (a) Galvanostatic cycling performance of Li||Li symmetric cells with PEO-LCy and pure PEO electrolytes at 0.2 mA cm−2. Insets: enlarged views of voltage profiles at different cycling stages. (b) Critical current density test of Li|PEO-LCy|Li cell. (c) SEM images of the lithium metal surface after cycling of Li|PEO-LCy|Li cell for 120 h at 0.1 mA cm−2 in different magnifications. XPS measurement of lithium metal anode surface after cycling for 100 h for both the cases of PEO-LCy and pure PEO electrolytes, with the signals of (d) C 1s, (e) Li 1s, (f) F 1s, (g) O 1s, (h) S 2p and (i) N 1s. Fig. 5 (a) Schematic of Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 battery. (b) Rate performance of Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 cell and (c) corresponding charge and discharge profiles at different rates. (d) Cycling performance of Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 cell at 0.2C and (e) corresponding voltage profiles at different cycle stages. (f) Cycling performance of Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 cell at 0.5C and (g) corresponding voltage profiles at different cycle stages. (h) Cycling performance of pouch-type all-solid-state Li||FeF3 cell based on PEO-LCy electrolyte at a current density of 100 mA g−1. (i) Photo of pouch-type Li||FeF3 cell. (j) Corresponding charge and discharge curves of pouch-type Li||FeF3 cell at different cycling stages. (k) Abuse test of Li||FeF3 pouch cell. Graphical abstract A trace filling strategy is proposed to address the issues of PEO-based solid electrolytes reinforced by a large content of filler, e.g., granular sensation increase, gravitational separation risk, and electrolyte membrane roughness. Polyethylene oxide (PEO)-based solid-state polymer electrolytes (SPE) face the challenges of insufficient ionic conductivity and uncontrollable Li dendrite growth. The filler strategy can reinforce anode interface stability, but at the cost of a large filler content (usually more than 10 wt%). This would increase the granular sensation, gravitational separation risk, and electrolyte membrane roughness with the creation of inhomogeneous Li+ transport channels between filler and polymer. Herein, we propose a trace filling strategy to address the above problems by introducing an amphoteric molecule L-Cysteine (LCy) as an eco-friendly and low-cost electrolyte additive. Only trace amount of LCy is required and integrated into PEO to form a homogenous, granule-less SPE with enhanced ionic conductivity and dendrite suppression capability. The ionic conductivity increases to 0.54 mS cm−1 at 60 ℃ after introducing only 1 wt% LCy. The amphotericity of LCy with basic –NH2 and acidic –COOH groups can promote the dissociation of Li salt and release more free Li ions through Lewis acid-base synergy, as well as the formation of multiple hydrogen bonds between PEO and LCy. The trace LCy additive swiftly leads to the formation of more ionic conductive interphases at both the anode and cathode sides. The composite SPE enables the stable cycling of Li metal for over 1400 h at 0.2 mA cm−2 and sustains a maximum current density up to 1.4 mA cm−2 in Li‖Li symmetric cells. The corresponding all-solid-state Li‖FeF3 full cells exhibit a high specific capacity up to 567 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and stable cycling performance for at least 700 cycles at 0.5 C with a high capacity retention. The excellent interface compatibility also guarantees the achievement of high-capacity Li-Fe-F conversion reaction even under the thin electrolyte membrane thickness and larger-scale pouch cell configuration. Keywords Trace filler strategy Amphoteric molecules Polymer electrolytes Li-Fe-F conversion Reaction All-solid-state batteries 1 Introduction Li metal solid-state batteries (SSBs) have been recognized as one of the most promising electrochemical energy-storage systems, given a step change in energy density compared with current lithium-ion batteries based on liquid electrolytes [1–6]. Inorganic solid state electrolytes (SSEs) based on representative oxides, sulfides, and halides exhibit satisfactory ionic conductivities of about 10−4–10−2 S cm−1 at room temperature, but suffer from brittle and fragile mechanical properties, which result in high interfacial contact resistance [5,7,8]. Comparatively, solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) based on polymer matrix are preferable for commercial application due to their excellent mechanical flexibility, interfacial compatibility, ease of fabrication, and cost effectiveness. Polymer (ethylene oxide) (PEO) is the most popular polymer matrix for SPEs because of its excellent operability and efficient lithium salt dissociation capability [4,6]. However, the ionic conduction in PEO-based SPEs mainly occurs in the amorphous part of PEO matrix, while the crystalline part delivers very limited ion motion. Therefore, ionic conductivity of PEO-based SPEs highly depends on the nature of polymer matrix in terms of its ability to solvate Li salts and the ratio of crystalline phase versus amorphous phase. Consequently, modification strategies are widely applied to improve the ionic conductivity of PEO-based SPEs [9]. The addition of fillers to SPEs can promote the dissociation of lithium salts, increase the concentration of ions in electrolyte system, and hinder the directional arrangement of polymer chains. Therefore the filler reinforced SPEs offer promising benefits due to their higher ionic conductivity without compromising mechanical performance or electrochemical stability. Plasticizers have been added to PEO to enhance their ionic conductivity [10]. Unfortunately, this strategy results in a reduction in mechanical strength, refractoriness and electrochemical stability of SPEs. Direct synthesis of PEO into polymer networks, such as those with comb-like or star-shaped structures, can significantly reduce PEO crystallization. However, many of the proposed synthesis processes have been found to be cumbersome or require harsh reaction conditions [11,12]. Addition of ion-conductor-type fillers like Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZO) and Li1.3Al0.3Ti1.7(PO4)3 (LATP) to PEO is another effective method [13,14]. Despite the fact that these conductor-type fillers provide adequate Li-ion conductivity in composite structures, the interfaces between heavy-metal-contained ceramic materials and polymers within SPEs may degrade over time due to potential side reactions or gravitational separation [15–17]. This degradation not only impairs the mechanical strength but also has a significant impact on the Li+ transport performance of SPEs during long-term cycling. Recently, functional fillers have emerged as the most promising category due to their multiple enhancement effects [9]. They are typically based on two dimensional (2D) materials or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which exhibit attractive properties such as robust ion conductivity, mechanical strength, effective electrolyte interface contacting and enhanced stability [18,19]. Ding et al. used ZIF-62 glass as a functional filler to simultaneously regulate the electrochemical performance, mechanical properties, and thermal stability of SPEs [20]. Hu et al. synthesized porous microspheres of g-C3N4 as electrolyte filler to effectively suppress lithium dendrite growth during cycling due to the high mechanical strength and nanosheet-built hierarchical structure of g-C3N4 [21]. However, in comparison to inorganic ceramic electrolytes, these functional filler/polymer composite electrolytes require a more intricate preparation process, which needs the effective amalgamation of fillers and polymers. What’s more, the amount of filler is relatively large, usually more than 10 wt% [21–23],which may not able to create homogeneous fast Li+ transport channels between fillers and polymer. Instead, they act only in the defined reunion areas for fast Li+ transport. Apart from this, the fluorinated conversion-type cathode pairing with Li metal anode can theoretically provide a specific capacity up to 712 mA h g−1. Unfortunately, it usually suffers from the deactivation and dissolution of conversion products, resulting in F-loss and rapid capacity degradation. The SSEs, such as ceramic-based SSEs or hard-soft PEO matrix, have been recently reported to improve the cycling performance of FeF3 cathode [21,22,24,25]. However, the full cell performance is still limited by the SSE microstructures and compositions. Herein, we introduce amphoteric molecules, L-Cysteine (denoted as LCy), as an eco-friendly and low-cost filler, with a low content (1 wt%), to integrate into PEO electrolyte to realize the high-performance PEO-based electrolyte (denoted as PEO-LCy). Because of the simple molecular structure of LCy and its rich functional groups (carboxyl, amino, and sulfhydryl groups), LCy is expected to enhance the lithium-ion transport and endow good compatibility between electrolyte and electrode. The carboxyl (–COOH), amino (–NH2), and thiol (–SH) groups in LCy each play crucial roles. The –COOH groups easily form hydrogen bonds with the oxygen atoms in PEO, creating a crosslinked network that enhances mechanical properties. The –NH2 groups coordinate with lithium ions, facilitating their migration. The –SH groups improve chemical stability and create a stable interface with lithium metal, preventing dendrite formation and enhancing cycling lifespan and safety of batteries. Benefitting from these, the ionic conductivity and Li+ transference number of PEO-LCy reach as high as 0.54 × 10−3 S cm−1 and 0.68 at 60 °C, respectively. Furthermore, the addition of trace LCy swiftly leads to the formation of more conductive anode and cathode interfaces with the suppression of Li protrusions and dendrites. As a result, the Li symmetric cell with PEO-LCy can maintain a stable cycling over 1400 h at 0.2 mA cm−2. What’s more, the good electrode compatibility with PEO-LCy guarantees the achievement of high-capacity Li-Fe-F conversion-based SSBs even under the thin electrolyte membrane thickness and lab-scale pouch cell configuration. 2 Results and discussion In a typical process, the LCy, LiTFSI, and PEO powders were added to an acetonitrile solution in a specific ratio, and a uniform solution was formed by continuous stirring at room temperature. After moulding a coating on a Teflon culture dish, the acetonitrile was completely evaporated in a vacuum environment. This coating was then peeled off to obtain a flexible film, which is highly bendable without any fracture. Fig. 1 a shows the schematic illustration of Li conduction process in PEO-LCy electrolyte. The LCy molecules invade into the molecular chains of PEO, and the intermolecular interaction in PEO is weakened because of the increase of molecular internal rotation resistance, leading to the decrease of crystallization zones in PEO [26]. Also, the existence of hydrogen bond between LCy (–COOH/–SN/–NH2) and PEO can physically increase the friction of PEO molecular chains, and the hydrogen bond induced cross-linked 3D network structure can further inhibit the wriggle of PEO segments [27,28]. These synergistically rigid-flexible coupling dynamics can locally restrain the movement of polymer chains of PEO and eventually prevent their recrystallization. The electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of SS|PEO-1%LCy|SS (SS: stainless steel) at different temperatures (30–70 ℃) are shown in Fig. 1b, from which the ionic conductivity of PEO-1%LCy electrolyte can be obtained. At 30 °C, due to the lower ionic conductivity, the impedance spectrum primarily exhibits a prominent semicircular arc. In this case, the ionic conductivity is calculated by taking the diameter of the semicircular arc, which represents the bulk resistance in electrolyte. As the ionic conductivity increases at higher temperature, the impedance spectrum shifts to a more linear behavior, with a high-frequency intercept with x-axis corresponding to the bulk resistance of electrolyte. Here, the ionic conductivity is directly derived from this intercept. The slope at low frequency corresponds to the diffusion of Li-ion inside solid phase. As the temperature rises, the bulk phase resistance of polymer electrolyte decreases to the very small level. The pure PEO electrolyte exhibits the low ionic conductivities of about 0.01 mS cm−1 at 30 ℃ and 0.12 mS cm−1 at 60 ℃ (Fig. S1), similar to previous report [29], and the conductivity increases to 0.23 mS cm−1 for PEO-1%LCy electrolyte at 30 ℃ after introducing 1 wt% LCy. This phenomenon can be explained based on the regulation functionality of fillers for polymer segments, and the addition of LCy decreases the crystalline region of PEO. As the temperature increases, the amorphous regions within PEO-1%LCy increase, further enhancing the ionic conductivity, which reaches 0.54 mS cm−1 at 60 °C (Fig. S2). The corresponding Arrhenius plots of PEO-LCy with varying LCy contents (0.5–20 wt%) are depicted in Fig. 1c. The ionic conductivity of PEO-LCy electrolyte improves along with the initial increase of LCy content, and it reaches the optimal state with the addition of only 1 wt% LCy. The further increase of LCy content brings adverse effect on ionic conductivity of electrolyte due to the discontinuous Li+ pathways caused by the aggregation of fillers. Note that the small content of filler is favorable for the maintenance of Arrhenius plots in a linear relationship, especially at the near room temperature regions. Otherwise the room temperature conductivity drops evidently. We calculate the activation energies (E a) for membranes with different LCy contents based on the Arrhenius equation. The fitting results show that the PEO-1%LCy membrane exhibits the lowest E a of 0.43 eV (Fig. S3), indicating the most favorable ion transport kinetics among the tested compositions. The reduced activation energy can be attributed to the synergistic role of L-cysteine in modulating the local polymer coordination environment. Therefore, we choose the PEO-1%LCy electrolyte sample for further analysis. The electrochemical stability window is evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) at 60 ℃ (Fig. 1d). The PEO-1%LCy electrolyte delivers a higher limit of oxidation steady voltage (∼4.8 V) than that of PEO-LiTFSI electrolyte (∼4.3 V), verifying a great potential of tiny LCy filler to improve electrochemical stability of SPE. This improvement is due to the hydrogen bond interaction between LCy and PEO, which protects the ether functional groups on PEO chains from degradation under high voltage. Based on scanningelectronmicroscopy (SEM) and scanning dispersive spectra (EDS) element mapping (Fig. 1e, Figs. S4 and S5), it can be confirmed that LCy with small content is sufficiently dispersed in PEO matrix from the spatial contribution of S and N element spots. The F element spots from Li salt appear to be denser. The SEM image shows the smooth morphology without granular surface. This texture indicates the potential dissolution of LCy in PEO matrix, promoting the homogeneity of composite electrolyte and facilitating the penetration of crosslinking interfaces. Furthermore, the optical images of formed PEO-LCy membrane are represented in Fig. 1f, and the membrane has a diameter of 17 mm and a thickness as thin as 18 µm. This PEO-LCy electrolyte displays super-flexibility, which can sustain various deformations including bending and twisting without fracture and avulsion. The favorable mechanical flexibility of PEO-LCy electrolyte can well satisfy the requirements of wearable devices. We also carried out tensile stress–strain tests on both the PEO-LCy and the PEO-LiTFSI electrolyte membranes (Fig. S6). The results show that although the PEO-LCy membrane exhibits the slightly lower tensile strength, its flexibility is significantly enhanced. This enhancement arises from the introduction of LCy, which induces the additional hydrogen bonding and plasticizing effects within polymer matrix. This disrupts the crystalline domains of PEO and weakens the intermolecular entanglements, which slightly reduces the tensile strength. However, these interactions also soften the polymer network and facilitate the polymer chain mobility under stress, leading to a marked increase in ductility and stretchability. This improved deformability is beneficial for accommodating interfacial stress during battery cycling and effectively resisting lithium dendrite penetration. To better elucidate the mechanism of improved ionic conductivity in PEO-LCy electrolytes, Raman spectra and density functional theory (DFT) calculation were carried out to substantiate the dissociation behavior of lithium salt in PEO-LiTFSI and PEO-LCy electrolytes. Fig. 2 a displays the Raman spectra of PEO-LCy containing 0–10 wt% LCy amounts. The characteristic peaks located at 621.1 cm−1 corresponding to the C–S stretching vibration, the peaks at 930.2 cm−1 corresponding to the S–H bending vibration, the peaks at 1029.7 cm−1 corresponding to the C–N stretching vibration, and the peaks at 1397.1 cm−1 corresponding to the COO− symmetric stretching vibration can be found in PEO-LCy electrolyte [30], indicating the existence of LCy fillers. Since trace LCy is introduced to polymer electrolyte in consideration of generating electrochemical stable electrode/electrolyte interface layer, the major ion conducting species in polymer matrix stem from LiTFSI component. In order to explore the chemical state of TFSI−, Raman spectra in the range of 728–760 cm−1 ascribed to the –CF3 bending vibration in TFSI−, are deconvoluted by Gaussian-Lorentzian fitting to determine the proportional change of free/coordinated TFSI− in electrolytes, and the results are shown in Fig. 2b. The peaks located at 738.9 and 744.9 cm−1 are attributed to the dissociated “free” TFSI− ions and the coordinated Li+-TFSI− ion pairs [31]. Hence, the dissociation degree of LiTFSI in electrolytes can be estimated through the calculation of free TFSI− proportion according to the following equation D i s s o c i a t i o n d e g r e e o f L i T F S I % = F 1 F 1 + F 2 × 100 % where F1 and F2 represent the peak areas of “free” TFSI− ions and coordinated TFSI− ions, respectively, in Raman spectra. As illustrated in Fig. 2b, the dissociation degree of LiTFSI in PEO-1%LCy electrolyte is as high as 89.5%, which is much higher than that of PEO-LiTFSI (62.3%), implying that only tiny amount of LCy filler is enough to greatly improve the dissociation of lithium salt. Note that the more addition of LCy on the contrary causes the decrease of dissociation degree of LiTFSI, which are 72.9% and 71.4% in the cases of 5%LCy and 10%LCy respectively. This can be explained by the aggregation tendency of excess LCy molecules, which induces the formation of heterogeneous microdomains within the polymer matrix. These aggregated domains disrupt the homogeneous distribution of coordination sites and compromise the structural integrity of the polymer-salt-additive interaction network. As a result, the formation of complete solvation shell around Li+ ion is hindered, and some Li+ ions may be insufficiently solvated or even recombine with free TFSI− anions. This leads to a shift in the dissociation equilibrium toward the associated state, thereby lowering the overall dissociation degree. Density functional theory (DFT) was performed to study the binding energies between TFSI− and PEO, between TFSI− and Li+, and TFSI− and LCy, as shown in Fig. 2c. The binding energy between Li+ and TFSI− is −5.24 eV (due to electrostatic interaction). Nevertheless, the binding of Li+ and TFSI− may not be the major state of TFSI− because of the relatively diluted concentration of Li salt (1 M) in this system [32]. The binding energy of LCy-TFSI− (−1.52 eV) is stronger than that of PEO-TFSI− (−1.01 eV), meaning that TFSI− anions prefer to combine with LCy after the dissolution and decoupling of LiTFSI. Once dissociated, the free Li+ ions are stabilized by coordination with the ether oxygen atoms in PEO chain (with a binding energy of −1.71 eV), indicating that PEO can act as an effective Li+ solvation matrix that facilitates Li+ migration through its segmental motions. This division of function, where LCy serves as a TFSI− scavenger and PEO acts as a Li+ carrier, explains the enhanced salt dissociation and ionic conductivity observed experimentally. The Li-ion transference number ( t L i + ) of PEO-LiTFSI is only 0.17 (Fig. S7) in agreement with the literature [33]. Notably, the t L i + of PEO-1%LCy is estimated to be 0.68 (Fig. 2d), nearly quadruple that of PEO-LiTFSI. Such a high t L i + could originate from the immobilization of TFSI− anions, which allows further free the associated Li+ cations. Fig. 2e exhibits the electrostatic potential distribution of PEO, LiTFSI and LCy. The electrostatic potential is depicted using a color scale, where the regions of high positive potential are represented by blue and green colors, and the regions of high negative potential are indicated by yellow and red colors. It can be observed that the proton hydrogens in the –NH2 and –COOH groups of LCy exhibit a high positive electrostatic potential, which is evident from the intense blue regions. On the other hand, the oxygens in PEO molecular chain exhibit a high negative electrostatic potential, as shown by the red regions. This significant difference in electrostatic potentials leads to a strong interaction between PEO chains and LCy groups. The electrostatic potential distribution of the PEO-LCy composite is highlighting the interaction between the two components (Fig. 2e). The integration of LCy into PEO matrix facilitates the formation of hydrogen bonds between the protonated hydrogens of LCy and the oxygen atoms of PEO, which facilitates the rapid detachment of lithium ions from the oxygen atoms in PEO chains. What’s more, the introduction of LCy enhances the dissociation of lithium salt due to the amphoteric nature of LCy, which can interact with both cations and anions, thus contributing to the improved ion migration ability. Additionally, the electrostatic potential distribution can be used to predict the migration pathways of lithium ions within this SPE system. According to Fig. 2f, g, the transition energy barrier of Li+ on PEO surface is 1.12 eV, whereas the LCy-PEO surface enables the lower energy barrier of 0.86 eV. Migration mechanism of Li+ in PEO and PEO-LCy are depicted in Fig. S8. LCy is prone to attenuate the interaction between lithium ions and polymers, therefore reducing the lithium-ion transport energy barrier and allowing lithium ions to move faster through the polymer chain. This effect is consistent with the excellent electrochemical performance for PEO-LCy system, as evidenced by Raman spectra (Fig. 2b) and t L i + determination. Molecular dynamics (MD) simulations were performed to investigate the interactions between LCy and PEO-LiTFSI. From the snapshots in Fig. 3 a, b, trace LCy doping tends to disrupt the coordination environment of Li+. In the PEO-LiTFSI system, Li+ ions exhibit a tight coordination with the surrounding oxygen (O) atoms and nitrogen (N) atoms of TFSI− anion (Fig. 3c). This strong coordination implies that Li+ ions are firmly bound within the system, and their mobility is limited. However, when LCy is introduced into the system, the coordination environment of Li+ ions undergoes significant changes, specifically resulting in a marked weakening of the original Li–O and Li–N bonding interactions. This weakening effect occurs because LCy molecules interact with TFSI− anion, effectively disrupting the strong electrostatic forces that initially hold the Li+ ions in close association with the O and N atoms of TFSI− anion. Consequently, the Li+ ions experience a reduction in their binding energy within PEO matrix, which facilitates a more facile migration of Li+ ions through PEO-LCy. The radial distribution function indicates the detailed coordination structures of Li+ for Li–O (TFSI), Li–N (TFSI) and Li–O (PEO) (Fig. 3d, e, Fig. S9). In Fig. 3d, the intensities of dominated peaks at 2.0 and 4.0 Å for Li–O (TFSI) display an obvious decline after introduction of LCy, implying that Li–O bonds are weakened and more bonded Li+ ions are released. In addition, the coordination numbers of Li–N and Li–O (TFSI with LCy) are lower than those of Li–N and Li–O (TFSI without LCy) in Fig. S9 and Fig. 3d, which indicate the easy dissociation of LiTFSI salt in PEO-LCy. The radial distribution function and coordination number of Li–O (PEO) in PEO-LCy system are roughly the same as those in PEO-LiTFSI system, indicating that the LCy-filler does not degrade the complexing of Li+ with ether oxygen atoms on PEO chain segments, which enables the sufficient lithium-ion transport. The mechanism of Li+ transport in PEO-LCy electrolyte is depicted in Fig. 3f. As LCy acts as active point to coordinate with the O and N atoms from LiTFSI, more Li+ ions would be dissociated from LiTFSI salt. On the other hand, the potential interaction of LCy with the chains of PEO is expected to reduce the crystallinity of PEO, enabling a high Li+ transport ability along the PEO chains. As a result, in the LCy-integrated PEO electrolyte, the lithium ion hopping is relaxed, leading to the formation of larger-flux channels for higher conductivity. To evaluate the long-term cycling stability and interfacial stability of PEO-LCy during lithium plating/stripping, symmetric lithium cells were constructed using lithium metal as an anode and SPE as an electrolyte interlayer. The Tafel plots in Fig. S10 reveal that the exchange current density of PEO-LCy (2.91 × 10−2 mA cm−2), much higher than that of PEO-LiTFSI (4.58 × 10−3 mA cm−2), demonstrating the accelerated charge transfer rate at the Li-polymer interface promoted by LCy filler. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the symmetric cells are tested at 60 ℃, under the current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 and areal capacity of 0.2 mA h cm−2. It reveals that the PEO-LiTFSI based cell just operates about 200 h and then a short circuit occurs, indicating the poor compatibility with lithium metal and inadequate suppression of dendrite growth. In sharp contrast, the PEO-LCy based cell successfully works over 1400 h without distinct fluctuation of voltage polarization, which is around 100 mV, suggesting the excellent resistance to lithium dendrites and strong electrolyte-lithium affinity. When doubling the current density and areal capacity to 0.4 mA cm−2 and 0.4 mA h cm−2 respectively, the Li|PEO-LCy|Li cell still enables a stable electrochemical cycling for at least 360 h with stable and small voltage polarization (Fig. S11). The rate performance of Li|PEO-LCy|Li cell was carried out to evaluate the critical current density (CCD) as shown in Fig. 4b. It shows that even at a high current density of 1.4 mA cm−2, there is no obvious short circuit for PEO-LCy. To better highlight the advantages of our PEO-LCy system over previously reported PEO-based electrolytes, Table S1 is shown to summarize the key performance metrics (ionic conductivity, content of filler and current density and cycle term of Li/Li symmetrical cells) based on various PEO modifications from literatures. This comparison clearly shows that our LCy-PEO electrolyte achieves a favorable combination of high ionic conductivity and low filler content, while enabling the stable Li plating/stripping under relatively high current densities and long-term cycling. Furthermore, the morphology of cycled lithium anode is observed by SEM imaging after the cycling of Li|PEO-LCy|Li cell for 120 h (Fig. 4c). A unique lamellar deposition of Li is observable with dense and smooth surface, indicating the effective suppression of lithium dendrite growth. The higher t L i + and conductivity of Li ions through SPE are responsible for the uniform deposition on the surface of lithium foil. To clarify the cycling stability resulting from PEO-based electrolytes and interfacial engineering, the ex situ X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were applied to determine the chemical compositions of interface layers from cycled Li electrodes. XPS spectra of C 1s, Li 1s, F 1s, O 1s, S 2p and N 1s for PEO-LiTFSI and PEO-LCy electrolytes after etching for 10 s are presented in Fig. 4d–i. For the interface with PEO-LiTFSI electrolyte, the abundance of C–C/C–H bonds stem from the organic species due to electrolyte decomposition. Thee organic species have the low ionic conductivity and mechanical strength, which are responsible for the poor electrochemical stability and early short circuit. In contrast, the PEO-LCy electrolyte system shows more Li2CO3 and less C–C/C–H bonds, along with the emerging Li x C compounds, which likely originate from the decomposition of –COOH groups in LCy molecules (Fig. 4d). The formation of Li x C compounds is expected to improve electrical conductivity, favorable for reducing interfacial resistance and enhancing rate performance. After the introduction of LCy, the ion conductive components of Li2S, Li3N, Li2O, and LiF are increased after long-term cycling (Fig. 4e), indicating the improved ion conductivity in solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) between Li and PEO-LCy. These Li-rich inorganic species in SEI can inhibit lithium dendrite growth. In Fig. 4h, the Li2S content is significantly higher in the PEO-LCy system, and a new C–S peak is observed at 163.3 eV [34], deriving from the decomposition of LiTFSI and –SH groups in LCy. The more trapping of LiTFSI in SEI is also observed in N 1s and F 1s spectra. The increased Li3N content in Fig. 4i is due to the decomposition of –NH2 groups in LCy molecules. Li3N has been improved to has high ionic conductivity, facilitating the uniform flowing of lithium ions across SEI [35]. These complex domains synergistically improve the cycling performance of symmetric cells, with Li2CO3 and LiF domains inhibiting electronic leakage and creating ion-conductive pathways [36]. The combination of Li2O and Li2S is expected to contribute to a robust interface with low carrier barriers [37]. Summarily, introducing trace LCy rapidly generates a chemically stable SEI from Li-salt and organic polymer, while the tiled particles of Li deposit mechanically suppress the growth of Li protrusions and dendrites. To address the stability of LCy’s functional groups during cycling, we also conducted Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis of the PEO-LCy composite electrolyte membranes before and after 100 h galvanostatic cycling in symmetric Li‖Li cells at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2. As the doping content of LCy is relatively low, the characteristic vibrations associated with its functional groups appear as the weaker signals in the overall FTIR spectra (Fig. S12). Nevertheless, meaningful information can still be extracted. Notably, the C–N stretching vibration (∼1138 cm−1) shows a slight intensity decrease after cycling. Similarly, the peaks corresponding to the COO− stretching (∼807 cm−1) and C–S vibration (∼694 cm−1) exhibit a slight intensity attenuation after cycling. These effects may be attributed to surface changes induced by the formation of the SEI layer during prolonged cycling, which can partially obscure or attenuate the FTIR signals from PEO-LCy. Nonetheless, the persistence of these characteristic peaks suggests that the functional groups (–NH2, –COOH, and –SH) remain chemically present and structurally preserved, despite minor consumption by interfacial modification. We also assembled the Li‖C@Al asymmetric cells (C@Al denotes carbon-coated Al current collector) to evaluate the Coulombic efficiency (CE) of lithium plating/stripping under a fixed areal capacity under a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2. As shown in Fig. S13, the Li|PEO-LCy|C@Al cell exhibits an initial CE of ∼80%, and the following CE gradually increases during cycling and stabilizes above 95% after 25 cycles. Notably, the cell maintains a high CE over 120 cycles, indicating the excellent reversibility of lithium deposition and stripping. This performance is attributed to the enhanced interfacial stability and favorable Li+ solvation environment in PEO-LCy system, where the synergistic interaction between LCy and PEO weakens the Li+-TFSI− ion pairing, increases the population of free Li+, and promotes the uniform Li nucleation. In contrast, the PEO-LiTFSI-based cell shows a low initial CE of ∼57%, with unstable efficiency during cycling and eventual cell failure at around the 50th cycle, suggesting severe side reaction and irreversible lithium loss. This stark contrast highlights the effectiveness of PEO-LCy electrolyte in suppressing parasitic side reactions and maintaining intimate interfacial contact. Conversion-type FeF3 cathode, due to its ultra-high theoretical energy density (850 Wh kg−1 and 1400 Wh L−1) and abundance of resources, is considered to be a potent competitor to current cathode materials [38–40]. However, it could result in the loss of active species and degradation of cycle reversibility because of its larger volume evolution and potential dissolution of Fe ions during cycling. The SPE based battery configuration is expected to mitigate these issues by taking advantage of the confinement effect and soft contact interface. However, developing solid-state batteries with conversion cathodes remains a significant challenge due to the slipping or disconnection of solid–solid interfaces. In this study, we are able to successfully operate FeF3-polymer all-solid-state batteries that are optimized by LCy filling. The Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 solid-state full cells were assembled and tested galvanostatically (Fig. 5 a). To ensure sufficient segmental movements of PEO chains, the electrochemical measurements were conducted at 60 °C. The Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 cells exhibit good rate performance from 0.1 C to 2 C (Fig. 5b, c). At 0.1 C, the initial discharge capacity is as high as 678.7 mA h g−1, close to the theoretical specific capacity of FeF3 (712 mA h g−1) based on three electron transfer reaction. At the higher rates of 0.2 C, 0.4 C, 0.8 C, 1 C, and 2 C, the cells deliver the reversible capacities of 526.4, 391.3, 300.3, 242.6 and 165.8 mA h g−1, respectively. After returning to 0.2 C, the discharge capacity can still recover to 370 mA h g−1 and can be maintained for more than 60 cycles. This effect indicates the satisfactory high-rate tolerability even for the solid–solid conversion process. It should be noted that the charge/discharge curves display the typical two-stage discharge curves where the initial conversion reaction can be identified by the plateau around 2.0 V. Then both the insertion (with lithium ions reversibly intercalated into cathode without causing major structural change between FeF3 and Li x FeF3) and conversion reactions are gradually coalesced during the rate increase, with the evolution of conversion products and their domain distribution during cycling [39]. We also performed a control experiment using PEO-LiTFSI electrolyte under identical rate conditions (Fig. S14). The PEO-LiTFSI cell delivers an initial capacity of 560 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C, which rapidly drops to 170 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C, and further declines to 43 mA h g−1 at 2 C. After returning to 0.2 C, the capacity only recovers to 153 mA h g−1, indicating severe irreversibility and sluggish kinetics. In Fig. 5d, e, the Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 cell exhibits the high specific capacity up to 567 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C, and the reversible capacity is still above 400 mA h g−1 after 80 cycles. The two-stage discharge plateaus can be well preserved during long-term cycling. Note that the lower current density (e.g., in 0.2 C) allows for a more thorough FeF3 conversion reaction with a higher initial capacity. This would result in the potential phase segregation and conductive network degradation during long-time cycling, therefore causing the gradual capacity fading. Notably, the cell can present a relatively stable cyclability up to 700 cycles with a Coulombic efficiency approaching 100% at 0.5 C, and hold a high capacity retention of approximately 80% after 500 cycles (Fig. 5f, g). Under the higher current density (e.g., in 0.5 C), the initial capacity is lower than the theoretical value of FeF3, meaning a fraction of active material does not participate the lithiation reaction during the one-cycle period due to the delayed electron transport. These unreacted active species can still participate the conversion reaction during the following cycles, responsible for the observed capacity activation phenomenon. These transient unreacted domains can serve as “buffer stakes” to mitigate the coarsening of reaction products and stabilize the as-formed phase boundaries. They are favorable for the volume confinement of active species and therefore the better capacity stability as observed under high-rate protocol. We also investigated the feasibility of high-mass-loading cathode, and prepared the FeF3 composite electrode with an active material loading as high as ∼10 mg cm−2, corresponding to an areal capacity as high as ∼3 mA h cm−2 in Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 solid-state cell operated at 60 °C (Fig. S15). Despite the limited cycling stability under this high-loading condition, the result demonstrates the feasibility of our polymer electrolyte system under practical areal capacity, which is rarely achieved in FeF3-based solid-state battery configurations. The degradation at high loading is attributed to several known challenges of PEO-based SPEs, including limited ionic conductivity and Li+ mobility in thick electrode, less sufficient electrode–electrolyte interfacial contact in the absence of liquid phase, potential volume change and sluggish kinetics of FeF3 during conversion reaction. This preliminary result provides an important proof-of-concept for the viability of high-loading FeF3 cathodes in PEO-based solid-state systems and further optimization is needed in the future. We also performed the charge/discharge cycling of a full cell based on pure PEO electrolyte at 0.2 C at 60 °C (Fig. S16). As expected, the Li|LiTFSI-PEO|FeF3 cell performs significantly worse. Specifically, the reversible discharge capacity is only around 300 mA h/g, indicating the incomplete FeF3 conversion. Moreover, the long-term cycling stability is poor, with a sharp abnormality in coulombic efficiency after 20 cycles, suggesting interface instability or side reaction. After the 30th cycle, the cell is essentially degraded. This result demonstrates that the pure PEO electrolyte causes poor electrochemical performance. As mentioned before, this thin polymer membrane with trace of LCy filler can be effectively employed for conversion-type FeF3 cathode. The feasibility of trace LCy filler is also validated in real pouch cells. We assembled the Li||FeF3 pouch-type cells as shown in Fig. 5h–j. This pouch cell presents the highly reversible discharge capacity up to 550 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1 , and the capacities remain at 350 and 200 mA h g−1 after 200 and 500 cycles, respectively. When the current density increases to 200 mA g−1, the reversible discharge capacities of the pouch cell can still remain at 362 and 188 mA h g−1 after 200 and 500 cycles, respectively (Fig. S17). Besides, the pouch cell can provide stable current to light the LED bulbs even though it suffers from various degrees of abuse, including bending, folding, puncturing and cutting (Fig. 5k). These treatments demonstrate the excellent safety performance and practicality of PEO-LCy under extreme conditions. In order to evaluate the compatibility of our PEO-LCy electrolyte with high-voltage cathode materials, which is indeed essential for validating the expanded electrochemical window, we also carried out the full-cell test using LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NCM811) as a representative high-voltage cathode, cycled in a voltage range of 3.0–4.2 V. As shown in Fig. S18, the Li|PEO-LCy|NCM811 cell delivers an initial discharge capacity of ∼180 mA h g−1, and maintains a reversible capacity of ∼121 mA h g−1 after 70 cycles at 65 mA g−1, demonstrating both the high-voltage compatibility and good cycling stability. As a widely used high-energy cathode with a cutoff voltage of 4.2 V, NCM811 offers a stringent and practical evaluation platform to validate the anodic stability of the electrolyte. Attracted by the high performance of this all-solid-state Li‖FeF3 cell, we further explored the kinetics analysis of full cells by cyclic voltammetry (CV) and galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT). As shown in the CV curves of Li‖FeF3 cell (Fig. S19), two-stage redox peaks are recognizable during both the cathodic and anodic processes. With the steady increase of scanning rate, a modest electrochemical polarization with redox peak shift could be observed from the CV curves. There is a normalization formula for CV kinetics analysis as follows [41] i V = k 1 v + k 2 v 1 / 2 where i V is the peak current at the potential position of V, v represents the corresponding scan rate, and k 1 v and k 2 v 1 / 2 are the current responses corresponding to capacitance-controlled and diffusion-controlled processes, respectively. This formula can be simplified as i V = a v b where a and b are the variable parameters related to charge storage mechanism of this system. This equation can be transformed into the following form l o g ( i ) = l o g ( a ) + b l o g ( v ) Based on this equation, we can calculate the value of b from the slope of linear fitting between l o g ( i ) and corresponding l o g ( v ) . When the b value is close to 1.0, it typically indicates that the reaction is dominated by the pseudo-capacitive effect. Conversely, when the b value is close to 0.5, it suggests that the electrode exhibits diffusion-controlled behavior [42]. During the actual electrochemical reactions, the redox peaks are shifted due to varying overpotential with scan rate and therefore the peak voltages are selected for the fitting of l o g ( i ) and l o g ( v ) . As demonstrated in Fig. S19b, the b values for both cathodic and anodic peaks fall within the range of 0.5 to 1. This range suggests a mixed control mechanism, where both pseudo-capacitive behavior and diffusion-controlled process are present. The existence of pseudo-capacitance behavior in FeF3 cathode is attributed to the surface redox reaction and interfacial storage mechanism that coexist with the bulk conversion reaction. The GITT analysis was performed to ascertain the ion diffusion coefficients (D) in FeF3 cathode at varying degrees of lithiation (Fig. 6 a–c). Before the GITT test, the cell undergoes a pre-cycling process involving 10 cycles at 0.2 C in order to achieve a stable and reversible state. Subsequently, the cell runs intermittently for 1 h at 0.04 C followed by a relaxation process for 6 h in an open-circuit state. This process is repeated until the fully charged or discharged state is reached. The D value can be calculated using the following equation, which is based on the second Fick’s law D = 4 π τ m B V m M B S 2 Δ E S Δ E τ 2 τ ≪ L 2 / D where m B , M B and V m denote the mass, molecular weight (112.8 g mol−1) and molar volume (3.56 × 10−5 m3 mol−1) of FeF3 cathode respectively, L and S denote the thickness (0.0204 mm) and area (0.5027 cm2) of cathode respectively, τ is the intermittent time (3600 s), Δ E S is the difference of open-circuit voltages after two adjacent relaxation processes, Δ E τ is the voltage difference during one titration step (referring to Fig. 6b). The diffusion coefficient D in the reaction of FeF3 with Li+ is basically in the range of 10−11–3 × 10−14 cm2 s−1 (Fig. 6c), which is not low for conversion cathode. Note that the minimum D values often appear at the starting stages of (quasi) platforms of conversion and reconversion reactions, with the evolution of multiphase conversion products and corresponding enrichment of phase interfaces. It demonstrates that the LCy-integrated PEO enables the good kinetic performance of cathode. To further estimate the promotion effect of electrolyte on the reversibility of conversion reaction in solid-state Li||FeF3 batteries, we conducted XPS measurement on the cycled cathodes disassembled from Li|LiTFSI-PEO|FeF3 and Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 coin cells in the terminal charging state after undergoing 10 cycles at 0.2 C. Fig. 6d–f show the corresponding Fe 2p, Li 1s, and F 1s spectra for both the cycled cathodes. With reference to the Fe 2p spectra, by contrast with the PEO-LiTFSI system, it is observed that the Fe0 peak at 706.2 eV is absent in the PEO-LCy system, and meanwhile the proportion of Fe3+-F component at 714.5 eV increases. This comparison indicates that integrating LCy into PEO contributes to the optimization of reversibility effect on FeF3 reconversion reaction. The reconversion irreversibility is caused by the potential F loss or deactivation, which would trigger the accumulation of more F-deficient species and a sufficient residual of metallic Fe0 as shown in the case of pure PEO-LiTFSI system. Therein, these electron-disconnected iron metal domains are not able to be fully fluorinated and activated during cycling. The fractions of Li-Fe-F and LiF signals are higher for the PEO-LiTFSI system (Fig. 6e), also indicating a more sufficient reconversion reaction for the PEO-LCy system. Therein, the Li2O signal is detected at 54.1 eV in the Li 1s/Fe 3p spectrum, likely stemming from the decomposition of LCy filler with –COOH group. The more thorough conversion reaction with the formation of more catalytic Fe metal domains should be responsible for the –COOH degradation at the cathode side. This effect also leads to the formation of Li x C/Li2S in the PEO-LCy system. The enrichment of Li-ion conductive Li2O, Li x C and Li2S components at the cathode-electrolyte interface (CEI) can compensate for interfacial ion transport especially when the defective LiF domains (as ionic wires) decrease with their splitting and reconversion after charge. In contrast to the cycled anode interface, the LCy modification causes the less trapping of TFSI− anion at the cathode side from F 1s spectra (Fig. 6f). The potential catalysis of conversion products (e.g., active Fe0 nanodomains) may trigger the decomposition or conversion of trapped salt anions into Li-F species at the CEI zone, which is expected to compensate for the inactivation or loss of Li-F species during cycling and is favorable for the reconversion reversibility during charging process. Summarily, the XPS results show that the LCy integration into polymer electrolyte can enhance the reversibility of Li-Fe-F conversion reaction, leading to improved cycling stability and rate capability even under an all-solid-state architecture. Furthermore, the quasi in situ EIS measurements were carried out to investigate Li transport kinetics at the electrode/polymer electrolyte interface. The Nyquist plots of Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 cells show the change in total impedance with the increase of cycle number. As shown in Fig. 6g, after initial activation, Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 cells exhibit a smaller change in total impedance, indicating excellent dynamical stability at the interfaces between electrodes and polymer electrolyte. To more accurately elucidate the roles of interphases on battery kinetic behavior, the tool of distribution of relaxation time (DRT) is employed (Fig. 6h). DRT is an analytical method to estimate the distribution of characteristic time, corresponding to the relaxation time based on EIS data. Different electrochemical processes correspond to different relaxation time distributions, so the DRT spectra can be obtained based on the equation below [43–45] Z ω = R ∞ + ∫ 0 ∞ γ ( τ ) 1 + j ω τ d τ The EIS spectra are transformed into a relaxation-based function, designated as γ(τ). Here, τ is the relaxation time, R ∞ is the limitation of the real part of Z as angular frequency ω approaches infinity. The peaks in γ(τ) at specific relaxation times represent the related electrochemical processes, and the peak area represents the impedance value. We also separated the kinetics of the anode and cathode sides by measuring different symmetric cells of Li||Li and FeF3||FeF3 configurations. Fig. S20a, b show the EIS spectra of Li||Li and FeF3||FeF3 symmetric cells at the initial stage and after 10 cycles, and Fig. S20c, d present the corresponding DRT results for these cells. Both DRT spectra consist of four peaks, each with a unique relaxation time that denotes a specific electrochemical process. Specifically, the peaks located at τ 1 represent the impedance process in the high-frequency region attributed to the ohmic resistance of PEO-LCy. The peaks located at τ 2 represent the process in the medium–high-frequency region, mainly consisting of solid electrolyte interphase resistance (R SEI), while the peaks τ 3 represent the process in the mid-frequency region, mainly consisting of the charge transfer resistance (R CT). Finally, the correlation peaks in the low-frequency region (at τ 4 ) are attributed to the diffusion process (R D) [46]. From Fig. S20c, it is evident that the γ(τ 2) value for Li||Li symmetric cell remains almost unchanged from the initial state to the state after 10 cycles, indicating that the solid electrolyte/electrode interphase remains stable and compatible throughout the electrochemical cycling. The decrease in γ(τ 3) peak after 10 cycles suggests an improvement in charge transfer pathways at electrode–electrolyte interface. Similarly, the significant reduction in γ(τ 4) peak indicates a decrease in ion diffusion resistance and electrochemical activation within electrode bulk. The DRT results for FeF3||FeF3 symmetric cell (Fig. S20d) show different behavior. The FeF3 electrodes are prelithiated before testing. Note that γ(τ 3) and γ(τ 4) show minimal changes after 10 cycles, indicating stable charge transfer and diffusion resistances in the cathode-electrolyte interface and cathode bulk. However, the reduction in γ(τ 2) peak after cycles indicates the formation of more conductive interfacial components between PEO-LCy and FeF3. From the above analysis, it is possible to assign the major impedance processes of Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 full cell to the contributions of anode and cathode by DRT during cycling. However, the similar process in different cell configuration has slightly different characteristic frequencies and shows slightly different behavior [47]. For the cycled Li|PEO-LCy|FeF3 cell, there are still four relaxation processes (Fig. 6h), with similar frequency regions of characteristic peaks as those for symmetric cells. During the cycling process, the τ 1 peaks remain relatively unchanged, indicating that the PEO-LCy composite electrolyte is stable in maintaining consistent ionic transport properties. The magnified view shows a gradual decrease in τ 2 peak with the increase of cycle number, indicating the CEI optimization with improved conductivity based on the enrichment of Li2O, Li x C and Li2S components [48], contributed by the cathode side as shown in DRT of FeF3||FeF3 symmetric cell. It is also observed that the intensity of τ 3 peak decreases dramatically after 15 cycles, suggesting an improvement of charge transfer especially at the anode side as indicated by DRT of Li||Li symmetric cell. The τ 4 reduction with the progress of cycles indicates a significant decrease in ion diffusion resistance within the bulk of electrodes. The cycling-induced better ion contact of PEO-LCy with Li metal and FeF3 is responsible for the first decrease and then stabilization of τ 3 and τ 4 peaks. The structural optimization of FeF3 cathode with the construction of built-in mixed conductive network after conversion reaction is also responsible for the shrinkage of these characteristic peaks [39,49]. 3 Conclusions In this study, we propose a trace filler strategy to develop a PEO-based composite electrolyte with granule-less texture and no gravitational separation between filler and PEO. The introduction of an amphoteric micro-molecule filler LCy, with a concentration as small as 1 wt% is enough to improve the conductivity performance and interface stability and compatibility. The –NH2 and the –COOH groups in LCy promote the dissociation of lithium salts and the release of more free Li ions through the Lewis acid-base cooperative effect, leading to an ionic conductivity of 0.54 × 10−3 S cm−1 and a transference number of 0.68 at 60 °C after introducing only 1 wt% LCy. DFT simulations further reveal that Li+ ions exhibit a reduced transition energy barrier and accelerated movement within PEO-LCy interface. Moreover, the introduction of a mere 1 wt% LCy additive with abundant functional groups can smartly lead to the in situ formation of ionic conductive SEI and CEI at both Li|PEO and FeF3|PEO interfaces. These complex interphases not only enhance the cycling stability of Li‖Li symmetric cells (with Li plating and stripping over 1400 h at 0.2 mA cm−2), but also result in the excellent rate performance and long-term cycling stability for all-solid-state Li‖FeF3 cells (with high-capacity retention of 80% over 500 cycles at 0.5C). Notably, the Li‖FeF3 pouch-type cells deliver a high discharge capacity of approximately 400 mA h g−1 even after 100 cycles at 100 mA g−1. This research highlights the potential of trace amount of amphoteric molecule additives to thin polymer electrolyte membranes and develop high-capacity, long-lasting all-solid-state lithium metal batteries especially based on conversion reaction. coredata.dc:description: Polyethylene oxide (PEO)-based solid-state polymer electrolytes (SPE) face the challenges of insufficient ionic conductivity and uncontrollable Li dendrite growth. The filler strategy can reinforce anode interface stability, but at the cost of a large filler content (usually more than 10 wt%). This would increase the granular sensation, gravitational separation risk, and electrolyte membrane roughness with the creation of inhomogeneous Li+ transport channels between filler and polymer. Herein, we propose a trace filling strategy to address the above problems by introducing an amphoteric molecule L-Cysteine (LCy) as an eco-friendly and low-cost electrolyte additive. Only trace amount of LCy is required and integrated into PEO to form a homogenous, granule-less SPE with enhanced ionic conductivity and dendrite suppression capability. The ionic conductivity increases to 0.54 mS cm−1 at 60 ℃ after introducing only 1 wt% LCy. The amphotericity of LCy with basic –NH2 and acidic –COOH groups can promote the dissociation of Li salt and release more free Li ions through Lewis acid-base synergy, as well as the formation of multiple hydrogen bonds between PEO and LCy. The trace LCy additive swiftly leads to the formation of more ionic conductive interphases at both the anode and cathode sides. The composite SPE enables the stable cycling of Li metal for over 1400 h at 0.2 mA cm−2 and sustains a maximum current density up to 1.4 mA cm−2 in Li‖Li symmetric cells. The corresponding all-solid-state Li‖FeF3 full cells exhibit a high specific capacity up to 567 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and stable cycling performance for at least 700 cycles at 0.5 C with a high capacity retention. The excellent interface compatibility also guarantees the achievement of high-capacity Li-Fe-F conversion reaction even under the thin electrolyte membrane thickness and larger-scale pouch cell configuration.
